image.altText: Aerial shot of a large dam

items.synopsis: Alcoa could have its current plans to mine assessed by WA's environmental watchdog for the first time in history, following drinking water concerns.

title.children: Perth drinking water concerns could trigger Alcoa environmental review

image.altText: A collage of two silhouettes, the KPMG logo, and cutouts of $100 notes.

items.synopsis: Consulting giant KPMG has been accused by whistleblowers of wasting public money, submitting inflated invoices and billing the Department of Defence for hours never worked.

title.children: It's raking in billions of dollars in public money. Now whistleblowers are accusing this consulting firm of ripping off the government

image.altText: Roger Cook speaks at a podium with Australian, WA and the Aboriginal flag in the background.

items.synopsis: The WA government's decision to scrap its controversial cultural heritage laws after a public backlash will give it the chance to bring its critics back on side — but it's an opportunity not without risk, writes Keane Bourke.

title.children: Roger Cook has plenty of reasons to scrap cultural heritage reforms, but one major risk remains

image.altText: A police exclusion zone following a fatal house fire on Russell Island

items.synopsis: Investigators are still sifting through the burnt-out house on Russell Island after the fire that killed a father and his five sons yesterday.

title.children: Police say cause of house fire requires 'closer scrutiny' after father and five sons killed

image.altText: Composite image of Andrew Forrest and Michael Woodley.

items.synopsis: With Fortescue and Pilbara native title holders unable to agree on compensation for "economic and cultural loss" caused by mining, the Federal Court will begin hearing evidence in Roebourne today.

title.children: Andrew Forrest's FMG, Pilbara traditional owners return to court over $500 million compensation battle

image.altText: A woman in a purple t-shirt reading vote yes weaving a basket while surrounded by others

items.synopsis: Supporters of the Yes campaign are still hopeful the referendum will pass but a growing number of No voters is putting it at risk, writes Dana Morse.

title.children: The Voice referendum campaign is becoming a tale of two polls and a political battle

image.altText: Two sets of gloved hands hold the head of a baby, its face scrunched up, while it is being born.

items.synopsis: Midwives across the country say workforce shortages are taking a heavy toll on maternity staff and the families they care for.

title.children: The hands delivering this baby belong to two young midwives, stepping into a profession under immense stress

image.altText: Female soccer players in gold jerseys embraces in celebration after scoring a goal

items.synopsis: Australia is set to play for a spot in the quarterfinals of the FIFA Women's World Cup tonight. Here's what you need to know before the Matildas run onto the pitch.

title.children: What time do the Matildas play tonight? Get up to speed

image.altText: A netball team gathers on court for a group shot holding an Australian flag as a sign says 'Champions' behind them.

items.synopsis: The Diamonds reclaim the last piece of silverware missing from their trophy cabinet by clinch their 12th Netball World Cup title.

title.children: Australia wins back Netball World Cup to send Ash Brazill out on a high

image.altText: A barista making coffee at a cafe

items.synopsis: Jarrod Heelan went "cold turkey" to quit drugs after his dad died. He says a detox centre in his Geraldton hometown would help others get clean.

title.children: Jarrod quit drugs without a detox service. He wants others to have access to support

image.altText: Hundreds of Banksia Securities creditors met in Kyabram, Shepparton and Ballarat.

items.synopsis: After a decade, retirees who lost money in the collapse of Banksia Securities Limited are a step closer to getting their money. But the story remains an epic tale of the rich and powerful exploiting their standing to rip off the vulnerable, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Class actions are meant to help level the playing field. So how did this one go so wrong?

image.altText: Rebel Wilson smiles towards the camera

items.synopsis: The 43-year-old has been in Savannah, Georgia filming her upcoming film Bride Hard, an action comedy where Wilson stars as a secret agent.

title.children: Rebel Wilson was hospitalised after a 'stunt accident'. She's working on one of the few films not affected by the actors strike

image.altText: A barber shop with a sign telling people it's a male only sanctuary

items.synopsis: An Adelaide barbershop that bans women from entering its premises in order to provide its clients with a "male sanctuary" has applied for an exemption to the Equal Opportunity Act.

title.children: Barber seeks exemption to Equal Opportunity Act to cut women from its clientele

image.altText: Two young men in woggles and hats hold up ginger beer at a scout camp.

items.synopsis: Australia is the latest contingent to withdraw from an international scout camp due to a typhoon forecast to hit South Korea, which is already in the midst of a sweltering heatwave.

title.children: Australian Scouts forced to withdraw from South Korean jamboree ahead of typhoon

image.altText: A Matildas striker crouches low to the ground as she runs away from goal with arms spread, as teammates celebrate a goal.

items.synopsis: Australia are favourites to defeat Denmark in the round of 16. But does the team see itself in the same way?

title.children: Can the Matildas unshackle themselves from their underdog story to dominate Denmark?

image.altText: Donald Trump, wearing a navy suit, holds his red tie down to stop it flapping as he descends airplane stairs

items.synopsis: The former US president says "there is no way I can get a fair trial" and he will seek Judge Tanya Chutkan's recusal as well as a change of venue.

title.children: Donald Trump seeks new judge in election fraud case

image.altText: Mushrooms stand on a patch of grass.

items.synopsis: Homicide detectives are still trying to get to the bottom of a suspected mushroom poisoning at a family meal in Victoria's east which led to the deaths of three people, who are being mourned as "pillars" of their community.

title.children: Suspected triple-fatal mushroom meal was served at relative's home, Victoria Police say

image.altText: A UH-60M Black Hawk in flight.

items.synopsis: Two new Black Hawks arrive in Australia, which will eventually form part of a 40-strong helicopter fleet to replace the army's troubled Taipans that remain grounded following last month's crash in Queensland.

title.children: Army's first new Black Hawks arrive as 'secretive' Taipan crash investigation continues

image.altText: Memorial of flowers and game controller handset and plush koala toy near Russell Island house fire scene

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Mayor says community 'still reeling' after deadly Queensland house fire: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The navy has recorded the highest number of sexual assaults in Australia's Defence force, in a new report released by the Director of Military Prosecutions. AAP reports that the documents reveal there were 47 sexual assault and related offences received by the office last year, up from 30 in 2021. Despite being a smaller service than the army, there were 21 sexual offences received from the navy last year (up from 12 in 2021), with 18 offences in the army (up from right in 2021) and eight in the air force (down from 10 in 2021). Sexual assault support lines: 1800 Respect National Helpline : 1800 737 732 Sexual Assault Crisis Line Victoria : 1800 806 292 Safe Steps Crisis Line (Vic) : 1800 015 188 Men's Referral Service : 1300 766 491 Lifeline (24-hour crisis line): 131 114 Victims of Crime Helpline : 1800 819 817
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Sexual assault claims in the Australian Defence Force rise in latest report

props.alt: A large Navy ship in water

children.content: (Defence: LSIS Daniel Goodman)
The navy has recorded the highest number of sexual assaults in Australia's Defence force, in a new report released by the Director of Military Prosecutions.
AAP reports that the documents reveal there were
47 sexual assault and related offences received by the office last year, up from 30 in 2021
Despite being a smaller service than the army,
there were 21 sexual offences received from the navy last year
(up from 12 in 2021), with
18 offences in the army
(up from right in 2021) and
eight in the air force

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Karen Williams, mayor of Redland City Council, is speaking on ABC News about the Russell Island blaze which killed a father and his five sons over the weekend. She says the tragedy will resonate with the community for quite some time. "Which is why Redland City Council spent most of yesterday making sure that we've got the appropriate resources on the island and on the mainland to wrap around the community and those people who are first responders or have been impacted by this tragic event," she says. Disaster chaplains and community support are made available to residents and a space has been set up for people who want to pay their respects or need assistance. Williams says the island, which is home to about 3,500 people, is a very small and tight-knit community. "Everybody knows everybody and, at the same time, they're all there to make sure that they support each other," she says. "I just think they are still reeling at this whole event. It's so tragic."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland's Russell Island community grieving after deadly house fire, mayor says

props.alt: A close up of a woman in a black jacket in her office

children.content: Redland City Council Mayor Karen Williams
(ABC News)
Karen Williams, mayor of Redland City Council, is speaking on ABC News about the
Russell Island blaze
which killed a father and his five sons over the weekend.
She says the tragedy will resonate with the community for quite some time.

"Which is why Redland City Council spent most of yesterday making sure that we've got the appropriate resources on the island and on the mainland to wrap around the community and those people who are first responders or have been impacted by this tragic event," she says.
Disaster chaplains and community support are made available to residents and a space has been set up for people who want to pay their respects or need assistance.
Williams says the island, which is home to about 3,500 people, is a very small and tight-knit community.
"Everybody knows everybody and, at the same time, they're all there to make sure that they support each other," she says.
"I just think they are still reeling at this whole event. It's so tragic."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Syrian state media says an Israeli missile attack on Syria's capital Damascus has killed four soldiers, wounded four more and caused "some material damage". "At about 2:20 in the morning today, the Israeli enemy launched an aerial aggression from the direction of the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, targeting some points in the vicinity of the city of Damascus," a military source reportedly says. Syrian air defences intercepted the Israeli missiles and shot down some of them, the source added. Israel has for years carried out attacks against what it has described as Iran-linked targets in Syria, where Iran's influence has grown since it began supporting President Bashar al-Assad in the civil war that started in 2011. Reporting by Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Syrian state media says four soldiers have been killed in an Israeli missile attack

children.content: Syrian state media says an Israeli missile attack on Syria's capital Damascus has killed four soldiers, wounded four more and caused "some material damage".

"At about 2:20 in the morning today, the Israeli enemy launched an aerial aggression from the direction of the occupied Syrian Golan Heights, targeting some points in the vicinity of the city of Damascus," a military source reportedly says.
Syrian air defences intercepted the Israeli missiles and shot down some of them, the source added.

Israel has for years carried out attacks against what it has described as Iran-linked targets in Syria, where Iran's influence has grown since it began supporting President Bashar al-Assad in the civil war that started in 2011.
Reporting by Reuters

image.altText: Six feamle soccer players, wearing white, look upset after losing, with one on her knees, crying

items.synopsis: Two-time defending Women's World Cup champions USA are knocked out in the round of 16 by Sweden, 5-4 on penalties in Melbourne/Naarm.

title.children: USA suffer historic World Cup knock-out after dramatic penalty shoot-out

image.altText: VAR showing a ball just over the line from Sweden's match-winning penalty against USA at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The reigning champions are knocked out by VAR and a phenomenal goalkeeper, as Sam Kerr is set to finally take the field. Here are five talking points from the Women's World Cup.

title.children: Five quick hits — Sweden sinks USA by this much and Sam Kerr set for first World Cup minutes

image.altText: Stingrays with Foord

items.synopsis: These players have a training story to cherish for a lifetime after Caitlin Foord dropped in on her old club to dazzle them and the TV cameras with her skills.

title.children: How a groundskeeper with a nifty kick turned out to be a Matildas star

image.altText: An Aboriginal flag in the foreground, Parliament House in the background

items.synopsis: Millennials and members of Generation Z have never voted in a national referendum before, but they may decide whether the constitution changes this year.

title.children: Could young people lead Australia to vote Yes in the Voice to Parliament referendum?

image.altText: A woman stands by a car with her arms crossed

items.synopsis: A mining boom and a government scheme to house its workers has made renting a home in this Northern Territory town almost impossible.

title.children: Vanessa lives in a shack outside Tennant Creek with no power or water. It was her only option

image.altText: Balupalu Yunupingu explains the importance of the message stick before handing it over to Noel Pearson.

items.synopsis: The confidence of Yes campaigners at Garma can be difficult to fathom when looking at the hard numbers and trend lines that usually dictate political campaigns, writes David Speers.

title.children: The numbers can't be ignored. Yes is behind, and it's trying new angles to appeal to anyone still on the fence

image.altText: An illustration of a boy staring out a window from behind.

items.synopsis: Almost 33 per cent of Australians feel disconnected socially, and one in six feels severely lonely, according to a landmark study. But there are ways to feel less alone.

title.children: 'They feel really ashamed': Millions of Australians are lonely, but some find it hard to admit

image.altText: People stand around in red boat while another boat come towards them

items.synopsis: At least six people are dead and dozens are missing as several ships across the Mediterranean sink amid record migration.

title.children: Several migrant ships sink off Italy and Tunisia

image.altText: A building on fire with bright flames on the inside and smoke above

items.synopsis: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy denounces the attack as a war crime as Ukraine also claims to have downed several Russian missiles.

title.children: Russia targets blood bank and airbase in latest strikes on Ukraine

image.altText: An elderly lady sits in front of a bookcase

items.synopsis: Renters searching for affordable housing have been at the forefront of Australia's housing crisis. But landlords say bad tenants and state-based reforms are making it tough for them too.

title.children: Been turned away from a rental? Here is why real estate agents, landlords say they are knocking people back

image.altText: Megan Rapinoe of USA kicks a penalty shot.

items.synopsis: Penalty shootouts are cruel at best, but this one sealed the most heartbreaking of exits for a hero of women's football; an exit all the more unfathomable because fate had been at her own feet, writes Kate O'Halloran.

title.children: A fairytale ending presented, but for once, Rapinoe and the USA couldn't take it

image.altText: Fire ant in extreme close up on a stick

items.synopsis: The Invasive Species Council says delays to the rollout of funding may be "catastrophic" for fire ant eradication efforts, based on its analysis of leaked government documents.

title.children: Fire ants winning battle against eradication due to 'bureaucratic delays', environment group says

image.altText: Cheyenne Paynter with french horn

items.synopsis: With most urban and suburban year 11 and 12 students in Tasmania still going to a dedicated seniors college, questions are being raised about the big teacher resources going to a handful of students in public high schools.

title.children: Tasmania's year 11 and 12 school system underwent a dramatic shake-up. Is it working?

image.altText: A close-up of a corporate pwc logo on a reflective glass building panel.

items.synopsis: Firms and advisers promoting tax exploitation schemes will face hundreds of millions of dollars in penalties as part of what the federal government is calling the biggest crackdown on tax adviser misconduct in Australian history.

title.children: PwC tax scandal prompts government to crack down on tax adviser misconduct

image.altText: A woman smiling holding a baseball bat.

items.synopsis: When Carly Moore walks out onto the diamond in Canada this week, she will become the first South Australian to represent Australia at a Women's Baseball World Cup. She's hoping to inspire more local females to step up to the plate.

title.children: Carly is the first South Australian to play in the Women's Baseball World Cup, but she vows not to be the last

image.altText: A man stares out at raging floodwaters in a village.

items.synopsis: A magnitude-5.5 earthquake strikes eastern China as rain continued to pelt the north-eastern regions in the wake of Typhoon Doksuri, adding more pressure to the country's struggle to recover its economy from the COVID pandemic.

title.children: China's economic losses from natural disasters surge to billions, adding more pressure to struggling economy
